2025-03-11T04:33:00Z;Nasdaq correction: Time to buy the dip on Nvidia?;"The Nasdaq Composite has moved into correction territory (down at least 10% from all-time highs). A significant contributor to that drop has been Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) stock
column2: which is down about 20% year to date
column3: as of this writing. The chipmaker reported outstanding results recently
column4: but investor concerns about tariffs and the U.S. suddenly looking like it could be headed toward a recession have rattled the market in the near term.

column1: For investors interested in Nvidia who have a long-term mindset
column2: this price correction presents a great opportunity to scoop up Nvidia shares on the cheap. Let's look at three reasons why the stock is a must-buy for the long term on this dip.

column1: 1. Nvidia is the artificial intelligence infrastructure leader
With an approximate 90% market share for graphics processing units (GPUs)
column2: Nvidia is the dominant leader among the chip designers that are powering the artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure buildout. While originally designed to speed up graphics rendering in video games
column3: Nvidia's GPUs' fast processing times have made them ideal for helping train large language models (LLMs) and running inference for AI.

column1: In addition
column2: the company's CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture) platform has helped create a wide moat for the company. Nvidia became the first company to allow GPUs to be programmed for tasks outside their original purpose back in 2006 through CUDA. As such
column3: developers learned to program GPUs using Nvidia's software platform.

column1: Rival Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ: AMD) didn't introduce its ROCm (Radeon Open Compute) software platform until about 10 years later in 2016. Meanwhile
column2: through CUDA-X
column3: which was built on top of CUDA
column4: Nvidia now has a full software stack comprised of libraries
column5: microservices
column6: and tools designed to accelerate applications in the areas of AI and high-performance computing.

column1: CUDA and CUDA-X continue to be the primary reason for Nvidia's dominance
column2: particularly in AI model training. In a recent study
column3: semiconductor research outfit Semianalysis found AMD's latest GPUs unusable for AI training out of the box due to software bugs
column4: while praising Nvidia's chips. As such
column5: Nvidia remains the company best positioned to continue to benefit from AI infrastructure growth.

column1: 2. AI data center infrastructure continues to grow
Despite Chinese AI company DeepSeek's claims of building an effective AI model cheaply (how effective it actually is is in dispute)
column2: the best-known way to advance AI models currently is through brute compute-power force. This means building out systems with more and more AI chip clusters.

column1: Recent AI model iterations have needed exponentially more GPU chips to be trained on than their predecessors. For example
column2: Meta Platform's Llama 4 LLM needed 10x as many GPUs to be trained on than Llama 3. Elon Musk-backed xAI
column3: meanwhile
column4: originally used 5x the GPUs (100
column5: 000) to build out its Grok 3 model before bumping it up to 200
column6: 000 GPUs.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: cloud computing companies
column3: along with other tech companies
column4: are pouring money into building AI data centers. The big three cloud computing companies plan to spend a combined $255 billion building out AI data centers this year to help keep up with demand.

column1: Cloud computing is an infrastructure-as-a-service platform
column2: and customers have been using these services to help customize and build their own AI models and applications. Meanwhile
column3: Meta plans to spend up to $65 billion in capital expenditures (capex) this year largely aimed at expanding its AI infrastructure
column4: while a consortium led by OpenAI and Softbank have pledged to spend $500 billion over the next few years building out AI data centers in the U.S. through Project Stargate.

column1: This all points to a lot of continued future spending on AI infrastructure in the years ahead. As such
column2: Nvidia remains well-positioned to continue to grow.

column1: 3. Nvidia stock is inexpensive

The third big reason to own Nvidia is that its stock remains attractively priced. The stock currently trades at a forward price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of 24 times 2025 analyst estimates and a price/earnings-to-growth ratio (PEG) of below 0.5. PEG ratios under 1 typically indicate a stock is undervalued
column2: and growth stocks will often trade at PEGs well above 1. Nvidia isn't a software-as-a-service (SaaS) company with a recurring and predictable revenue stream
column3: so it isn't going to command the same type of valuation multiple as these types of companies -- nor should it. However
column4: its current valuation is inexpensive
column5: given that we still appear to be in the early days of AI and that AI infrastructure spending will continue to rise. As such
column6: the recent pullback looks like a solid buying opportunity in the stock long term."

column1: 2025-03-11T12:15:00Z;This Simple Investing Blunder Could Cost You 8%+ Dividends;Investing Mistakegetty I recently got some reader feedback that made me realize something: When it comes to our favorite income investments—8%+ yielding closed-end funds (CEFs)—there are still a lot of misconceptions out there.   It’s key that we put those right
column2: because they’re causing some investors to miss out on CEFs
column3: and the big (and often monthly) dividends they provide. And I know I don’t have to tell you that in turbulent times like these
column4: high payouts like those are a lifesaver.  This reader wrote in response to a recent piece I wrote about how CEFs can be better than ETFs
column5: pointing out two things:    The three CEFs I mentioned in the piece have higher expense ratios than passive funds. There are cheaper ways to buy stocks that the CEFs I wrote about in that article own (more on them below)
column6: such as Microsoft (MSFT)
column7: a major holding of all three of these CEFs.  Let’s address both of these concerns because they are valid—and both are often cited by financial advisors and the mainstream media as reasons to avoid CEFs and invest in ETFs
column8: like the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY).  Following that advice can cost you significant dividends: CEFs currently yield 8.5% on average
column9: while SPY
column10: the largest ETF by market cap
column11: yields a paltry 1.4%. So
column12: let’s dig into the first issue. MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column13: April 10Microsoft’s Free Upgrade Offer For 500 Million Windows Users  Closed-End Funds Have Higher Fees … Right? I am not going to disagree with the feedback here
column14: because it is true. On average
column15: CEFs have management fees of 2.9%
column16: which sounds very high compared to what you’d pay on the average index fund.  I should note before we go further
column17: though
column18: that the two CEFs we’ll get into below (both of which appeared in the article)—the Virtus Artificial Intelligence & Technology Opportunities Fund (AIO) and the Columbia Seligman Premium Technology Growth Fund (STK)—charge much less: about 2.7% for AIO and 1.1% for STK.   The fees for the BlackRock Science and Technology Trust (BST)
column19: the other fund mentioned in that article
column20: are about the same as STK
column22: but we’re going to focus more on the other two funds
column23: and the opportunity we have in them
column24: today. Here’s where our reader picked up on a common misunderstanding about CEF fees
column25: suggesting that these fees are taken out of the income and total returns these funds provide. In other words
column26: if the fee were to be taken out of AIO’s dividend
column27: its 7.8% yield would actually amount to 5.1%
column28: net of fees. But this isn’t how CEF fees work. Let’s take the most important detail first: The fees that CEFs charge are taken out of the fund’s portfolio before distributing dividends. The fund will not remove it from the yield you receive: If AIO yields 7.8%
column29: that means you will get $780 a year for every $10
column30: 000 you invest. The fees are taken care of on the back end
column31: before AIO reports its capital gains and pays out distributions
column32: so all the profits I’m about to show you are net of fees. Are the fees justified? In my opinion
column33: getting $78
column34: 000 on a million-dollar nest egg is worth it
column35: since the low-fee alternative offers $14
column36: 000 in dividends on that same million bucks. Also
column37: I should point out that those CEF fees tend to remain as low as possible because of competition. The fees that CEFs charge are a combination of administrative fees
column38: payment to fund managers (which is often the smallest part of the fund’s assets
column39: typically around 0.07%)
column40: and payment for things like leverage costs (both of these funds typically borrow money to fund investments
column41: and AIO is currently borrowing more than STK
column42: which is why its fees are higher). In the end
column43: though
column44: this one chart is why I think the fees are justified
column45: even without accounting for these funds’ much higher yields.CEFs OutperformYcharts Both AIO (in blue) and STK (in purple) have outperformed the S&P 500 since AIO’s inception (it was released in late 2019
column46: which is why this chart goes only that far). And STK’s outperformance goes back much further.STK Total ReturnsYcharts Now
column47: to be sure
column48: these funds are weighted toward tech
column49: but it is also worth pointing out that the S&P 500 has been increasingly weighted to tech stocks (now about 45% of the index)
column50: which explains some of the outperformance here. But with fees as “high” as the ones they’re charging
column51: you’d expect SPY to be more competitive (again net of fees). To be sure
column52: the SPY shareholder paid less in fees. But the SPY shareholder also missed out on $1.137 of profits for every dollar they would have put into STK when it launched. Cheaper Ways to Buy Stocks? The second criticism also has some merit
column53: although maybe not in the way the reader meant. Let me explain.CEF PremiumsYcharts Both of these funds have a fixed number of shares they issue to the general public (this is fixed at the IPO). This is why the fund is called a closed end fund. While those shares trade on exchanges
column54: like any stock
column55: the issuer can’t issue new shares to grow the fund. The price of a share of a CEF will fluctuate according to supply and demand
column56: which means its market price can drift up or down from the liquidation value of all of its assets on the open market
column57: which is called the net asset value
column58: or NAV. Above you can see AIO is trading at a 6.5% premium to NAV as I write this
column59: while STK’s 1.5% premium is smaller than the 10%+ premiums it’s had in the past
column60: and is pretty close to trading at par. So
column61: yes
column62: you can get Microsoft cheaper than you can by buying it with AIO (by the way
column63: MSFT is 3.24% of AIO’s portfolio
column64: its second-largest position). How? By buying STK! But of course
column65: these are still both premiums. Lucky for us
column66: we can do even better
column67: by purchasing a heavily discounted CEF like the 9.4%-yielding Liberty All-Star Growth Fund (ASG)
column68: a recommendation of my CEF Insider service trading at a 7.9% discount to NAV
column69: with Microsoft as its top position
column70: at 4% of assets
column71: followed by NVIDIA (NVDA) at 3.3%. And check this out.Swappable CEFsYcharts See how ASG (in blue) is at that 7.9% discount as of this writing
column72: while AIO (in purple) is at a 6.5% premium
column73: but in 2020
column74: ASG traded at a premium and AIO traded at a discount? If you’re thinking there’s an opportunity here to buy ASG when it’s discounted
column75: sell when it’s at a premium
column76: then buy AIO when it’s at a discount and do the opposite trade when AIO swings to a premium
column77: you’re right. This isn’t just what some niche hedge funds do. It’s also the kind of move we’re always looking to make at CEF Insider. Michael Foster is the Lead Research Analyst for Contrarian Outlook. For more great income ideas
column78: click here for our latest report “Indestructible Income: 5 Bargain Funds with Steady 8.6% Dividends.” Disclosure: none Editorial StandardsForbes Accolades

column1: 2025-03-11T16:11:47Z;Nvidia’s Revenue Surges on ‘Insane’ AI Demand: Can NVDA Stock Keep Up;"
NVDA

has been at the center of the semiconductor industry since the artificial intelligence (AI) frenzy began. Its cutting-edge graphics processing units (GPUs) are becoming increasingly important as demand for AI computing rises. The company reported another strong quarter and a strong end to its fiscal 2025
column2: fueled by “insane” AI demand. Nvidia’s revenue increased from $4.6 billion in fiscal 2015 to an impressive $130.5 billion in fiscal 2025. Nvidia’s stock price has risen 1
column3: 771.6% over the last five years
column4: reflecting this demand for its AI-centric GPUs
column5: particularly the Blackwell architecture.

column1: Despite its results for fiscal 2025
column2: Nvidia’s stock is down 18% this year
column3: driven by recent market dynamics such as geopolitical tensions and trade uncertainties with China
column4: which have caused some volatility.

column1: Active Investor: FREE newsletter going behind the headlines on the hottest stocks to uncover new trade ideas
Nonetheless
column2: Wall Street rates this hyper-growth AI stock as a “Strong Buy
column3: ” expecting a 105% increase if it reaches the high price target of $220. The company is set to release its Blackwell Ultra and Rubin — its next-generation chip — at Nvidia’s developers conference on March 17. Let’s find out if the stock is a buy now. Fiscal 2025 Was Extraordinary for Nvidia

column1: In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2025
column2: total revenue increased 78% year-over-year to $39.3 billion
column3: while adjusted earnings increased 71% to $0.89 per share. Data Center remains the leading revenue contributor
column4: driven by AI growth. Revenue in this segment increased by 93% to $35.6 billion
column5: driven by strong demand for Blackwell. Revenue in the Gaming and AI PC segment fell by 11% in the fourth quarter
column6: but this was offset by a 103% increase in Automotive and Robotics revenue and a 10% increase in Professional Visualization revenue. For the full fiscal year 2025
column7: revenue surged 114% to $130.5 billion while adjusted earnings jumped 130% to $2.99 per share. CEO Jensen Huang stated in the quarter that the company successfully increased production of its flagship Blackwell AI supercomputer to meet rising demand for high-performance computing solutions.

column1: Nvidia continues to maintain a robust balance sheet despite significant investments in AI expansion. At the end of Q4
column2: it had cash
column3: cash equivalents
column4: and marketable securities totaling $43.2 billion. It also generated free cash flow of $60.7 billion in fiscal 2025
column5: paying out $834 million in cash dividends and $33.7 billion in share repurchases.

While Nvidia continues to perform well
column2: trade concerns loom over the company. Investors are concerned that President Donald Trump’s stricter export restrictions
column3: including a complete ban on H20 chips
column4: will have a significant impact on Nvidia. Currently
column5: China accounts for 13% of total revenue by customer billing location in fiscal 2025. Nvidia faced a similar situation earlier in 2023

column8: the U.S. market accounted for the majority (47%) of total revenue in fiscal 2025
column9: up 127% from fiscal 2024. In addition
column10: revenue in Singapore and Taiwan increased by 246.7% and 53.5%
column11: respectively
column12: year on year. This is a significant accomplishment in the face of export concerns to China. Investors will have to wait and see how Nvidia handles any trade restrictions that may arise this time around.

column1: 2025-03-12T03:43:00Z;Will Nvidia stock keep dropping in 2025?;"With shares down 20% year to date
column2: Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) has been off to a bad start in 2025
column3: even though its chip business continues to fire on all cylinders. Is the market predicting an end to the generative artificial intelligence (AI) hype cycle? Let's dig deeper to determine what the next nine months might have in store for the industry's leader.

column1: Fourth-quarter earnings were not bad
When a company's stock starts falling
column2: it's easy to blame poor operational performance. But that hasn't been the case for Nvidia. Fourth-quarter earnings show a business that is still firing on all cylinders. Revenue soared 78% from a year ago to a quarterly record of $39.3 billion
column3: driven by strength in the company's data center segment
column4: where it makes advanced AI chips for running and training large language models (LLMs).

column1: While Nvidia started as a gaming chip designer
column2: expensive data center hardware has become its bread and butter. Its latest AI chip
column3: Blackwell
column4: is estimated to cost a whopping $30
column6: 000 per unit. But these new products boast dramatic improvements in power and efficiency compared to their predecessors
column7: potentially allowing clients to save money using them. According to CEO Jensen Huang
column8: demand is ""insane.""

column1: That said
column2: everything isn't peaches and cream. Nvidia experienced a three-point drop in fourth-quarter gross margins (to 73%)
column3: but that was likely because of temporary challenges associated with the rollout of its new Blackwell chips. Management expects the trend to continue in the first quarter
column4: with gross margins dropping to 71% as it ramps up production.

column1: The market isn't impressed
At the time of writing
column2: Nvidia's shares are down 14% from the release of earnings on Feb. 26. This dip suggests the market isn't very impressed with the company despite its high growth rate and the successful rollout of its Blackwell chips. Some might blame this on the falling gross margins. However
column3: the bigger challenge may come from long-term demand.

column1: In February
column2: Microsoft shocked the tech world when it scrapped some leases for data centers in the U.S. The software giant is believed to be one of Nvidia's top consumers
column3: and a reduction in its data center capacity could indicate a desire to reduce its exposure to the industry.

column1: While Microsoft probably won't give up on AI
column2: its CEO
column3: Satya Nadella
column4: suggests the technology isn't creating much meaningful value yet. If one of the industry leaders says this openly
column5: other Nvidia clients (such as Alphabet and Meta Platforms) may feel the same way behind the scenes.

column1: Further alarm bells are coming from another major Nvidia client
column2: OpenAI. Last month
column3: the generative AI start-up finalized a design with TSMC to make its own custom chips to reduce its reliance on third-party suppliers. Custom chips are designed for specialized workloads
column4: so they have fewer unnecessary components
column5: making them cheaper and more efficient compared to the one-size-fits-all GPUs typically provided by Nvidia.

column1: If major clients scale back their AI investments and turn to custom chips
column2: Nvidia's growth potential could be seriously eroded.

column1: What's next for Nvidia?
With a market cap of $2.6 trillion
column2: Nvidia is already a huge company. And future upside looks limited
column3: especially as investors become more concerned with challenges like falling gross margins and potential demand erosion. That said
column4: shares also look unlikely to crash in 2025.

column1: With a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) multiple of just 25.5
column2: Nvidia shares are valued only slightly higher than the Nasdaq-100 estimate of 25
column3: making them quite affordable and reducing the risk of downside. The stock is likely to remain flat this year unless there is a severe deterioration in macroeconomic conditions
column4: such as a recession."

column1: 2025-03-14T09:00:34Z;Nvidia Stock To $60?;NVDA StockTrefis Trefis  Question: How would you react if you held Nvidia stock (NASDAQ: NVDA) and its value fell by 60% or more in the upcoming months? Although this might seem extreme
column2: such an occurrence has happened before and could repeat itself. Earlier this year
column3: Nvidia stock experienced a sell-off
column4: dropping from approximately $148 in mid-January to around $115 now
column5: which represents a nearly 23% decrease. This decline has been fueled by several factors
column6: such as the introduction of more resource-efficient AI models like China’s DeepSeek and worries that decelerating investments in generative AI might reduce the demand for Nvidia’s GPUs. Additionally
column7: the overall market is undergoing a significant sell-off
column8: spurred by increasing concerns about a U.S. recession following tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump on major trading partners. Separately
column9: see Is A New CEO Enough To Get Intel Back On Track?  Here’s the point: The key takeaway is that during a downturn
column10: NVDA stock might incur substantial losses. Data from 2022 indicates that NVDA stock lost more than 60% of its value in only a few quarters. Currently
column11: Nvidia stock has decreased from $148 to $115 in roughly two months. This raises the question: could the stock continue its downward trend and reach approximately $60 if a similar situation were to unfold? Naturally
column12: individual stocks are generally more volatile than diversified portfolios. Therefore
column13: if you are looking for growth with reduced volatility
column14: you might consider the High-Quality portfolio
column15: which has outperformed the S&P 500 and generated returns of over 91% since its inception.   Why Is It Relevant Now? Slowdown in AI Demand: Over the last two years
column16: companies have significantly invested in training AI models
column17: with Nvidia’s GPUs becoming the preferred option due to their performance and efficiency. The short-term outlook remains robust
column18: as tech giants such as Google and Microsoft are increasing capital expenditures for 2025 to expand their AI cloud infrastructures. Nevertheless
column19: demand may eventually taper off. Since AI model training is predominantly a one-time
column20: compute-intensive process
column21: it could eventually decelerate. As models increase in size
column22: incremental performance improvements are anticipated to diminish
column23: and the supply of high-quality training data might become a limiting factor. Consequently
column24: as the demand for training declines
column25: GPU sales could also decrease. Therefore
column26: as discussed in our analysis here on the macro picture
column27: the U.S. economy might enter a downturn
column28: potentially even a recession
column29: which could further affect GPU sales. Because AI investments continue to be unprofitable for most companies
column30: they may be prime candidates for cost-cutting measures during an economic downturn. This situation could significantly impact Nvidia.  The transition to more resource-efficient AI models could also affect Nvidia. China’s DeepSeek model
column31: launched in January
column32: attracted attention for prioritizing software-driven optimization instead of relying on hardware
column33: which could potentially reduce the demand for GPUs. The company reports that it spent only $5.5 million to train its V3 model
column34: which is only a fraction of the hundreds of millions that firms such as OpenAI are said to have spent. Since DeepSeek’s model is open source
column35: major tech companies might adopt similar cost-cutting strategies. If this approach is widely implemented
column36: it could further reduce the demand for AI computing power. For further information
column37: see how DeepSeek impacts Nvidia   The U.S. government has imposed export control restrictions on most of Nvidia’s latest AI chipset products destined for China
column38: with the exception of the H20 chips
column39: citing national security concerns. Nevertheless
column40: reports indicate that gray market resellers are using entities registered outside of China to purchase servers equipped with Nvidia’s latest products from companies in various countries
column41: including Singapore
column42: Malaysia
column43: Taiwan
column44: and Vietnam. This is particularly concerning as Singapore has emerged as Nvidia’s second-largest market
column45: generating approximately $23 billion in sales in FY’25 (around 18% of revenue)
column46: compared to only $2.3 billion (8% of revenue) in FY’23. Singapore has now initiated an investigation into these potential loopholes. Such developments could potentially affect Nvidia’s overall revenue to some degree. For further details
column47: see how Trump’s tariffs affect Nvidia stock.  MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday

column51: compared to a 33.9% decline for the S&P 500   • The stock fully recovered to its pre-crisis peak by 11 May 2020 Global Financial Crisis (2008) • NVDA stock declined by 85.1% from a high of $0.99 on 17 October 2007 to $0.15 on 20 November 2008

column1: 2025-03-15T14:02:00Z;This 15.6% Dividend Is A Smart ‘Buy The Dip’ Play;"Buy on the dipgetty There are two things I need to bring to your attention right now
column2: especially if you’re an income investor. One is my outlook for the market
column3: as volatility really hits home.  The other is a 15.6%-yielding(!) fund that just changed its name and ticker—and really grabbed contrarians’ attention in the process.   Let’s start with what’s really going on with this wild market.  The NASDAQ is now down more than 10% from its peak price
column4: and stocks on the whole are down for the year. I don’t expect this to last very long. My take: 2025 is likely to be a year of volatility rather than a year of decline.  Short-Term Dips Against a Long-Term Bull Backdrop Even so
column5: the volatility we’ve seen so far is relatively new. It was only the middle of last month that stocks started making a clear reversal from their long climb
column6: and the NASDAQ 100 is still up 12.6% annualized over the last three years as I write this
column7: while the S&P 500 is up an annualized 9.6%. Market DipYcharts Just a quick look at this chart tells you that buying the dip during this period has been a winning strategy. It also tells us that both indices are setting up for another dip-buying opportunity
column8: where stocks will fall to a point where they become irresistible. MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column9: April 10Microsoft’s Free Upgrade Offer For 500 Million Windows Users  COVID Has Reduced the Odds We’ll See Another 2008 During volatile markets
column10: however
column11: the psychological pressures are tough
column12: with sharp declines and trillions of dollars of wealth seemingly vanishing in a matter of days. This has always been a problem for markets
column13: but I think it’s less of a problem now
column14: for one reason: COVID-19.  This might sound a bit strange
column15: so let me explain. At the start of the pandemic
column16: trillions of dollars disappeared in hours. People were literally prohibited from economic activity
column17: as they were forced to stay in their homes. Oil prices actually went negative.   And yet stocks recovered
column18: both because of monetary policy (the Fed swooped in with emergency rate cuts and massive buys of government bonds—so-called “quantitative easing”) and
column19: after that
column20: technological progress (including changes in infrastructure responding to the pandemic
column21: such as new supply chains; new medical technologies; and
column22: of course
column23: AI). In other words
column24: investors have already seen the worst and it’s fresh in their minds
column25: so even if we face a recession over the next year or two
column26: stocks are unlikely to collapse like they did in 2020 or 2008. So
column27: in a sense
column28: this time is different
column29: but not in the way one might think: People are less likely to give in to total fear (or 2020-like despair!) as the business cycle weakens. Which means that while stocks are likely to fall
column30: they’re not likely to collapse. Buying the Dip In such a situation
column31: a smart play is to buy the dip slowly
column32: steadily and strategically. Since fear is unpredictable
column33: we can’t wait for the market to bottom and swoop in to buy everything
column34: but we can start buying when there’s a correction
column35: buy a little more as it worsens
column36: and buy even more when it becomes a full-on bear market. And we can essentially double our “dip-buying discount” by purchasing stocks within a closed-end fund (CEF) trading at an attractive discount to net asset value (NAV
column37: or the value of its underlying portfolio). That’s where the BlackRock Technology and Private Equity Term Trust (BTX)
column38: payer of that outsized (to say the least) 15.6% dividend. BTX is the fund’s newest ticker
column39: which BlackRock changed from BIGZ last month. It also changed the name from the old monicker: the BlackRock Innovation and Growth Term Trust. As the name now says
column40: the fund invests part of its portfolio in private equity
column41: which can have bigger returns than public stocks in the long run
column42: while the “term” refers to the fact that the fund will come to maturity in 12 years. (Although there is fine print stating that the fund can convert to a perpetual fund
column43: and I fully expect this to happen
column44: so I don’t pay much attention to the “term” in the name here). The most important thing here (besides the huge dividend
column45: of course) is the discount
column46: which has been narrowing lately:BTX Discount NarrowsYcharts Since the melodramatic fear-induced selloff of 2022
column47: BTX’s discount has narrowed as investors realized that a 20%-off sale on the fund’s tech-stock holdings
column48: including Marvell Technology (MRVL) and NVIDIA (NVDA)
column49: was a sweet deal. BlackRock
column50: the fund’s management firm
column51: even realized this and started a stock-buyback program in early 2024. There’s just one problem (or at least there was): BTX (under its former incarnation
column52: BIGZ) lagged other BlackRock tech CEFs. But these days the fund is worth your attention. From BIGZ to “Bigger X” The changes to this fund run much deeper than a rebrand. BlackRock also made major revisions to its mandate
column53: letting it invest even more in tech stocks. Now
column54: at least 80% of its assets will be in public and private tech companies
column55: instead of the previous focus on small- and mid-cap growth stocks. That mandate didn’t work because small-cap stocks have underperformed other types of stocks for years
column56: as you can see in the benchmark index fund for small caps
column57: in blue below
column58: compared to the NASDAQ (in orange) and the S&P 500 (in purple).Small Caps LagYcharts This wasn’t always the case
column59: and the reason why small caps underperform more now than they used to is another article unto itself. In short
column60: this was one of the reasons why I was wary of BTX when it was BIGZ. Ironically
column61: BIGZ wasn’t as “big-focused” as it should have been. That has changed
column62: along with BTX’s fund managers
column63: with the fund now being run by Tony Kim and Reid Menge. This is great news because Tony and Reid also manage the BlackRock Technology Opportunities Fund (BGSAX)
column64: which has run the table on the indices
column65: including the NASDAQ
column66: a particularly tough one to beat. This kind of outperformance deserves a premium
column67: which BTX will likely get eventually. Until then
column68: the fund remains attractive when it trades at a discount
column69: as it is now. Michael Foster is the Lead Research Analyst for Contrarian Outlook. For more great income ideas
column70: click here for our latest report “Indestructible Income: 5 Bargain Funds with Steady 8.6% Dividends.” Disclosure: none Editorial StandardsForbes Accolades"

column1: 2025-03-20T21:48:02Z;HCA Healthcare Is One Healthy Business;CHINA - 2024/06/23: In this photo illustration
column2: the American healthcare business HCA Healthcare ... More (NYSE: HCA) logo seen displayed on a smartphone with an economic stock exchange index graph in the background. (Photo Illustration by Budrul Chukrut/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images One of the biggest losers from the Mag 7 during earnings season was Nvidia (NVDA). I called a top for NVDA back in August 2024 and am not surprised to see it fall precipitously after reporting excellent earnings. The narrative that valuation does not matter is being disproved before our very eyes – along with many other false narratives that have plagued our society. If you’ve been following my reports on the company’s stock
column3: you would know that the recent drop in price is still not nearly enough to make the stock attractive.   NVDA is not alone. Crowded trades and overvalued stocks are everywhere. Good stocks are harder and harder to find as the market was hitting new highs. Accordingly
column4: I see opportunity in market pull backs. I see a golden era for stocks over the next couple of years as markets exorcise more false narratives (remember NFTs…haha) and embrace fundamentals again.  Meanwhile
column5: my firm’s proven-superior research continues to give an edge in finding good stocks. I work harder and smarter with my firm’s Robo-Analyst AI to scour the markets and the data to identify the stocks
column6: ETFs and mutual funds with the best risk/reward.   I previously made HCA Healthcare Inc (HCA) a Long Idea in June 2020
column7: and have reiterated my bullish view on the stock many times. Since my original report
column8: HCA has outperformed as a Long Idea by 137%
column9: rising 224% while the S&P is up 87%. Even after outpacing the overall market
column10: HCA Healthcare remains a strong business and very attractive stock.  HCA offers favorable Risk/Reward based on the company’s:  consistent top- and bottom-line growth
column11: growing patient and hospital numbers
column12: strong position as the industry leader
column13: high dividend and share repurchase yields on shares
column14: and cheap stock valuation.  What’s Working MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column15: April 10Microsoft’s Free Upgrade Offer For 500 Million Windows Users  Consistently Growing Fundamentals HCA Healthcare has steadily grown its top- and bottom-line since 2007.  HCA Healthcare has grown revenue by 6% and net operating profit after-tax (NOPAT) by 8% compounded annually since 2007. See Figure 1. The company has improved its NOPAT margin from 10.2% in 2007 to 11.9% in 2024 while increasing invested capital turns from 1.32 to 1.48 over the same time. Rising operational and capital efficiency drive return on invested capital (ROIC) from 13% in 2007 to 18% in 2024.   Figure 1: HCA Healthcare’s Revenue and NOPAT Since 2007HCA Revenue & NOPAT 2007-2024New Constructs
column16: LLC Patient Admissions and Hospital Locations on the Rise Year-over-year (YoY) in 2024
column17: HCA Healthcare’s:  same facility revenue increased 7.9% same facility admissions increased 4.9% same facility inpatient surgical volumes increased 2.2% same facility emergency room visits increased 4.9%  Longer-term
column18: the company has grown its admissions (general measure of inpatient volume) YoY in 8 out of the last 10 years. HCA Healthcare’s total admissions grew from 1.8 million in 2014 to 2.2 million in 2024
column19: or 2% compounded annually. Over the same time
column20: the company has expanded the number of hospitals it operates from 166 to 190. See Figure 2. Figure 2: HCA Healthcare’s Number of Admissions and Hospitals: 2014 – 2024HCA Admissions & Hospitals 2014-2024New Constructs
column21: LLC Medical Spending Tailwinds Hospital operators
column22: such as HCA Healthcare
column23: benefit from consistent
column24: and long-term
column25: tailwinds of an aging population and rising healthcare costs. In 2022
column26: 17% of the U.S population was 65 years or older. That percentage is expected to increase to 22% by 2040. The population of those aged 85+ is also expected to double from 2022 to 2040. As populations age
column27: healthcare spending increases. In fact
column28: per capita healthcare spending for those aged 65-84 is 1.6x higher than those aged 45-64 and 3.1x higher than those aged 19-44. Rising spend from an aging population drives projections for continued growth in hospital spending. According to the Peterson KFF Health System Tracker
column29: the annual hospital spending is expected to grow:  4.8% in 2025 4.6% in 2026 5.9% in 2027 5.7% in 2028 5.8% in 2029 5.4% in 2030 5.3% in 2031 5.4% in 2032  With its industry leading position and superior profitability (more on that below)
column30: HCA Healthcare is well-positioned to capitalize on steady growth in healthcare spending for years to come. Attractive Dividend and Repurchase Yield Since 2018
column31: HCA Healthcare has paid $3.8 billion (5% of market cap) in cumulative dividends and has increased its quarterly dividends from $0.35/share in February 2018 to $0.72/share in March 2025. The company’s current dividend
column32: when annualized
column33: provides a 0.8% yield. HCA also returns capital to shareholders through share repurchases. From 2018 through 2024
column34: the company repurchased $28.1 billion (34% of market cap) of shares. $16.9 billion of this repurchase activity occurred from 2022-2024. In January 2025
column35: HCA Healthcare’s board of directors authorized a new $10 billion share repurchase program. Management noted in the 4Q24 earnings call that they “anticipate completing a significant portion in 2025.” Should the company repurchase shares at its 2024 rate
column36: it would repurchase $6.0 billion of shares in 2025
column37: which equals 7.3% of the current market cap. When combined
column38: the dividend and share repurchase yield could reach 8.1%. Long Track Record of Quality Cash Flow Generation HCA generates enough free cash flow (FCF) to cover both its share repurchases and regular dividend payments. From 2018 to 2024
column39: HCA generated $30.9 billion in FCF while paying $3.8 billion in dividends and $28.1 billion in repurchases
column40: for total capital return of $31.9 billion. I like companies that choose to return so much capital to shareholders instead of spending it on executive bonuses or acquisitions. See Figure 3. Figure 3: HCA Healthcare’s Free Cash Flow Vs. Cash Dividends Paid: 2018 Through 2024HCA FCF and Dividends 2018-2024New Constructs
column41: LLC HCA Healthcare has generated positive free cash flow (FCF) in every year of my model on an annual basis. On a quarterly basis
column42: the company has generated positive FCF in 46 of the past 52 quarters. Since 2018
column43: HCA Healthcare generated $30.9 billion (23% of enterprise value) in FCF. See Figure 4. Figure 4: HCA Healthcare’s Cumulative FCF Since 2018HCA Free Cash Flow 2018-2024New Constructs
column44: LLC Proven Industry Leader HCA Healthcare was the most profitable healthcare company amongst its peers when I originally wrote my Long Idea report
column45: and it remains #1 today. It is also the largest hospital operator by revenue and number of locations. HCA Healthcare’s ROIC and invested capital turns are higher than all peers
column46: while the company’s NOPAT margin surpasses all but one of its publicly traded competitors. Competitors in this analysis include Encompass Health (EHC)
column47: Tenet Healthcare (THC)
column48: Universal Health Services (UHS)
column49: and more
column50: per Figure 5. Figure 5: HCA Healthcare’s Profitability Vs. Peers: Trailing Twelve Months (TTM)HCA Profitability vs CompetitorsNew Constructs
column51: LLC What’s Not Working Skilled Labor Is Hard to Come by in Healthcare Skilled labor in the healthcare industry remains in short supply. Job satisfaction for Registered Nurses (RN) and Advanced Practice Registered Nurses (APRN) remains low since COVID-19 due to increased levels of stress and excessive work hours. Many nurses also left the workforce after Covid. Worse yet
column52: a significant segment of the nursing workforce is nearing retirement age
column53: while too few new nurses are entering the workforce. According to the American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN)
column54: nursing enrollment is not growing fast enough to meet the projected demand for RN and APRN services. Hiring enough labor continues to be a headwind for the whole healthcare industry
column55: including HCA. However
column56: the company is taking steps to recruit and retain quality employees. In the 4Q24 earnings call
column57: management noted that employee engagement is “at an all-time high”
column58: which has allowed the company to “reduce turnover and improve the capabilities of our facilities with having continuity and staffing…” Furthermore
column59: the company continues to hire nurses from Galen College
column60: one of the largest nursing schools in the U.S.
column61: in which HCA Healthcare acquired a majority stake in 2020. Unknown Costs of Tariffs The cost of goods is rising
column62: and the potential for newly administered tariffs to drive costs even higher remains a risk for many companies. In the 4Q24 earnings call
column63: HCA Healthcare management noted that they’ve been working on tariff mitigation strategies for years to manage the cost of supplies needed to operate its hospitals. Importantly
column64: management noted that in 2025
column65: 70% of its supplies are already contracted with firm pricing
column66: which could help mitigate any increased supply cost when and if mass tariffs are enacted. Importantly
column67: HCA Healthcare is already priced as if tariffs and labor costs will hurt the business and result in deteriorating profitability. Management’s ability to mitigate these challenges creates increased upside in shares
column68: as I’ll show below. Shares Are Pricing in Zero Growth Below
column69: I use my reverse discounted cash flow (DCF) model to analyze expectations for different stock price scenarios for HCA. At its current price
column70: HCA’s price-to-economic book value (PEBV) ratio is 1.0
column71: which means the market expects its NOPAT to never grow from current levels. For context
column72: HCA has grown its NOPAT by 8% compounded annually since 2014 and 7% compounded annually since 2007. In the first scenario
column73: I quantify the expectations baked into the current price. If I assume:  NOPAT margin immediately falls to 9% (equal to lowest ever NOPAT margin vs.12% in 2024 and average of the past five years) through 2034
column74: and revenue grows at 4% a year through 2034 (compared to 7% compounded annually in the last five and ten years) then  the stock is worth $319/share today – nearly equal to the current stock price. For reference
column75: the revenue growth in this scenario would be below consensus expectations of 5.7% growth in 2025 and 5.1% growth in 2026. In this scenario
column76: HCA’s NOPAT grows just 1% compounded annually from 2025 – 2034
column77: which is well below historical growth rates. Shares Could Go 36%+ Higher at Consensus Growth Rates If I instead assume:  NOPAT margin immediately falls to 10% through 2034
column78: revenue grows at consensus rates in 2025 (5.7%)
column81: and revenue grows at 2027 consensus rate (5.5%) each year thereafter through 2034
column82: then  the stock is worth $435/share today – a 36% upside to the current price. In this scenario
column83: HCA’s NOPAT would grow 4% compounded annually from 2025 to 2034. Should the company’s NOPAT grow more in line with historical levels
column84: the stock has even more upside. Figure 6: HCA Healthcare’s Historical and Implied NOPAT: DCF Valuation ScenariosHCA DCF Implied NOPAT New Constructs

column1: 2025-03-23T11:00:00Z;Five Critical Indicators To Gauge Recession Risk;The decline in stock prices combined with plunging consumer sentiment and uncertainty surrounding ... More tariffs has uncreased uncertainty about future economic growth. Since stock prices ultimately depend on earnings
column2: the pace of economic growth is crucial input to future stock performance.getty After briefly hitting correction territory in the previous week
column3: which is defined as a 10% decline from an earlier high
column4: stocks had a modest rebound last week. The S&P 500 sits 7.6% below its mid-February high. The Magnificent 7
column5: consisting of Microsoft (MSFT)
column6: Meta Platforms (META)
column7: Amazon.com (AMZN)
column8: Apple (AAPL)
column9: NVIDIA (NVDA)
column10: Alphabet (GOOGL)
column11: and Tesla (TSLA)
column12: has faired worse with a drubbing of 18.5% since mid-December. The pressure on stocks stems from an economic growth scare and policy uncertainty surrounding tariffs.  Market ReturnsGlenview Trust
column13: Bloomberg Stock Correction: Implications Of A 10% Decline In Stock Prices With the S&P 500 closing over 10% below its February 19 high on Thursday
column14: March 13
column15: stocks officially entered a correction. In the twenty-one U.S. stock market corrections since 1980
column16: the average return in the 12 months following was 13.4%
column17: which on the surface would lead to significant optimism regarding future returns. If the data is sorted between periods when the U.S. economy entered recession within those 12 months after the correction
column18: the results are less compelling at a 1.9% average gain. Of course
column19: if an economic downturn is avoided
column20: the results have been spectacular on average at 19.1%.  Average Stock Returns After S&P 500 CorrectionGlenview Trust
column21: Bloomberg Weakening Economic Forecasts The strong bond between avoiding recession and better returns following a stock correction makes monitoring the economy's health even more critical. Economists' consensus estimate of 2025 economic growth has dipped slightly to 2.2%
column22: nowhere near recessionary levels. Unfortunately
column23: economists have a poor track record of accurately predicting economic growth with enough lead time
column24: and consensus estimates tend to lag behind real-time data.  Consensus U.S. Economic Growth ForecastsGlenview Trust
column25: Bloomberg  Economic models attempting to forecast the current quarter of GDP growth were developed to address the challenges associated with consensus estimates. These estimates adapt to the most recent economic releases to predict growth. This methodology has its challenges but adds additional color to the economic backdrop. The Atlanta Fed model points to a contraction in economic activity in the first quarter
column26: which is probably overstated because much of that downward estimate comes from a marked increase in imports to avoid future tariffs. The St. Louis Fed’s model remains in positive territory. The forecast difference between the two is vast for their first-quarter GDP estimate. After last week's Federal Reserve meeting
column27: the committee noted that “uncertainty around the economy outlook has increased.”    Estimated Frist-Quarter U.S. Economic GrowthGlenview Trust
column28: Bloomberg High-Frequency Recession Indicators While accurately forecasting an economic downturn in advance with any accuracy is exceptionally challenging
column29: monitoring some high-frequency data can help get an early warning about increased recession risks. These indicators were chosen because they are updated weekly or daily and have shown a strong correlation with economic activity. Indeed
column30: other indicators are crucial
column31: but they are typically only available monthly
column32: sometimes with a significant time lag. MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel UsersTrump Approval Rating Tracker: Three Post-Tariff Surveys Show Decline‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column33: April 10 Jobs The labor market is probably the most crucial part of the economy since consumer spending eventually wanes without wages to fund the purchases. Initial claims for unemployment benefits are reported weekly
column34: but the four-week moving average of claims is used here to reduce volatility. While initial claims are above the lows
column35: the level is not exhibiting a strong uptrend or at a level consistent with economic woes.Initial Jobless ClaimsGlenview Trust
column36: Bloomberg The other weekly job data is ongoing claims for unemployment benefits
column37: which are also off its lows and show a slow uptrend. This indicates that it is taking longer for those losing their jobs to find a new one. Remember that the number of employees in the U.S. has more than doubled since 1970
column38: so even though the current roster of those receiving unemployment benefits is as high as it was during the 1969-1970 recession
column39: the numbers aren’t comparable. The bottom line is that the labor market is softening but has not yet reached recessionary levels.Continuing ClaimsGlenview Trust
column40: Bloomberg Credit Spreads The corporate bond market should undoubtedly be part of the mosaic to monitor the economy’s health. Baa corporate bond data has a long history and arguably provides a look at the “typical” credit quality of companies
column41: as Baa credit rating is the lowest level of investment-grade bonds. The spread is the yield investors demand beyond U.S. Treasury bond rates to compensate for the default risk from buying corporate bonds. These spreads expand when investors worry that more bond defaults could be on the horizon
column42: typically driven by deteriorating economic conditions. While the spreads on Baa corporate debt are above recent lows
column43: the increase seems insufficient to trigger substantial fear of any impending economic downturn.Corporate Bond SpreadsGlenview Trust
column44: Bloomberg Financial Conditions The Chicago Fed produces the National Financial Conditions Index weekly. It looks at 105 measures across three categories
column45: risk
column46: credit
column47: and leverage
column48: to create a measure of financial conditions. According to the Chicago Fed
column49: “Positive values of the NFCI have been historically associated with tighter-than-average financial conditions
column50: while negative values have been historically associated with looser-than-average financial conditions.” The chart shows that these periods of tighter-than-normal financial conditions have often been associated with recession. Like the previous measures
column51: financial conditions have worsened but remain below warning levels.Financial ConditionsGlenview Trust
column52: Bloomberg Cyclical Stock Performance The more economically sensitive cyclical stocks have recently been underperforming the less economically sensitive defensive stocks. This suggests that an economic growth scare is one cause of the recent stock weakness. While it should continue to be monitored
column53: the relative weakness of cyclical stocks has improved off its most recent lows and isn’t at the level seen before past recessions.Performance Of Cyclical StocksGlenview Truat
column54: Bloomberg Yield Curve The 10-year Treasury minus 2-year yield is probably the most well-known predictor of recession. Historically
column55: when the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury falls below the 2-year yield
column56: also called yield curve inverting
column57: a recession is coming. Since the 1970s
column58: a yield curve inversion has occurred before every recession. The only blemishes on its record are the 1998 and mid-2022 inversions
column59: which produced no subsequent economic recessions. The U.S. economy did see a significant slowdown in the first half of 2022 but rebounded in the second half. Unfortunately
column60: even when the signal is correct
column61: it has variable lead and lag times. The yield curve still has a better prediction track record than the economists and is used in about every Federal Reserve model
column62: so it is worth watching despite its warts. The curve is not currently inverted
column63: so this model forecasts no recession.The Yield Curve & RecessionsGlenview Trust
column64: Bloomberg What To Watch This Week The economic calendar releases for the week are not of the highest importance. The two most notable are February durable goods orders on Wednesday and personal income and spending on Friday. Last week
column65: the Federal Reserve left its projected rate cuts at two but increased the inflation and unemployment forecasts. In addition
column66: the median forecast for GDP growth was lowered. Markets saw this as a somewhat dovish signal and pushed expectations closer to three cuts for 2025
column67: with the first in June.Number Of Fed Rate Cuts ExpectedGlenview Trust
column68: Bloomberg Conclusions Correctly forecasting a recession is challenging in the best of times
column69: but the post-COVID-19 period
column70: with its irregular economic cycles
column71: makes it even more perilous. These high-frequency indicators should provide a reasonable early warning system for a sizable economic contraction. Currently
column72: the odds point to an economic slowdown rather than a recession
column73: which bodes well for reasonable returns from the correction bottom. As always
column74: there are no easy calls when it comes to forecasting the short-term movement of stocks or the economy
column75: especially in a period of increased uncertainty around the severity of the tariffs. For example
column76: though most are rightly concerned about the downside risk from tariffs
column77: there is an upside if somehow this pressure results in better trade terms for U.S. companies. There is always uncertainty. So
column78: investors should have a portfolio with enough cash and bonds to cover short-term expenses. This cushion can help moderate the impact of stock declines on a portfolio and allow one to withstand the inevitable stock declines to experience the benefits of long-term ownership. Within the stock portion
column79: focus should be paid to companies that can weather economic dislocations and perhaps even take advantage of them
column80: regardless of their stock price movement. Follow me on Twitter or LinkedIn. Check out my website.Disclosure: Glenview Trust may hold any stocks mentioned in this article within its recommended investment strategies.Editorial StandardsForbes Accolades

column1: 2025-03-25T13:53:00Z;3 Big Dividends That Have Proven The ‘Experts’ Wrong Again;"MISTAKES TO AVOIDgetty Here’s some good news in these uncertain times: Most investors who’ve invested for the long haul are well-equipped to deal with this selloff. That’s because
column2: over the last five years
column3: stocks have been on an absolute tear.   In that period
column4: the S&P 500 has delivered an average annual total return of 19.1%
column5: as of this writing. That’s more than double the average of about 8% in the last century.  Looking At Various Timeframes Can Skew Our View Think back five years for a moment. Back then
column6: the stock market’s prospects looked bleak
column7: indeed
column8: as we were at the beginning of the pandemic-driven selloff. In the middle of March 2020
column9: lockdowns had just begun in the U.S. (the first one was on March 16
column10: in San Francisco
column11: and March 19 was the first statewide lockdown).  Thinking back to that troubled period highlights something important to remember when it comes to investing: Be careful not to take the current circumstances and project them over the long run
column12: because historically the market’s long-term direction is up
column13: especially over periods much longer than five years.   Early 2020 also tells us something when it comes to trying to discern if the stock market is overpriced or underpriced: Just looking at a certain time period of stock returns to try to tell whether or not stocks are a bargain is misleading because of something called base effects.  In other words
column14: your returns will be impacted by where you start looking
column15: which can sometimes cause some big distortions. Hot Performers In A Hot Market That’s always good to bear in mind
column16: of course. But it’s still interesting to look at periods of extreme outperformance and tease out those assets that did better still. Finding one might lead us to a real gem—especially if we can pick it up at a bargain. MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column17: April 10Microsoft’s Free Upgrade Offer For 500 Million Windows Users  With that in mind
column18: let’s look at some funds—high-yielding closed-end funds
column19: to be precise—that actually returned more than 19.1% annualized in the last five years.  This is important because many wealth advisors and market gurus say that actively managed funds can’t beat the market. Yet these three funds can—and have—even in an extremely hot market like the one we saw after COVID-19 got real.   I should be honest and say right now that the reason for this outperformance is that these funds invest in corners of the market that have dominated in that time
column20: as well as assets beyond the S&P 500. These are the main reasons why they’ve outperformed. But this precisely points to why diversifying across both sectors and assets is a proven strategy—it gives us exposure to some outperformance
column21: even in the best of times. That
column22: in turn
column23: boosts the value of our overall portfolio in the long term while helping cushion us from sudden
column24: nasty downturns like the one at the start of the pandemic. Or
column25: for that matter
column26: the one we’re seeing now. Plus
column27: these three funds have another compelling feature: big dividends. Two of them yield over 6%
column28: and one yields 9.5%
column29: so you can see how they don’t just give us the ability to diversify—they also give us the opportunity for a massive income stream that index funds just can’t offer. The benchmark S&P 500 index fund
column30: the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY)
column31: for example
column32: yields just 1.2%. So
column33: let’s jump in
column34: starting with the “worst” performer of our trio and wrapping up with our best. Market-Beating CEF #1: A 6.3%-Paying Tech Fund Returning 25% Annualized Our first fund returned an astounding 205% over the last five years. That’s mainly because the Columbia Seligman Premium Technology Growth Fund (STK) focuses on tech stocks: Broadcom (AVGO)
column35: NVIDIA (NVDA)
column36: Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL) are all top holdings. With that in mind
column37: its outperformance is no surprise. But unlike most tech funds
column38: STK yields 6.3%—actually on the low side for CEFs
column39: which yield around 8% on average. Even so this fund remains an unusually powerful way to draw a healthy income stream from the reality of tech encroaching on every part of our lives. There’s just one issue here: When it comes to CEFs
column40: we always strive to buy when a fund is trading at a discount to net asset value (NAV
column41: or the value of its underlying portfolio) and STK trades near par as I write this. This may mean STK will see a market-price decline to bring it to the kind of valuation its peers have. But if this smartly run fund hits a 5% discount to NAV or greater
column42: I see it a “no-brainer” buy. Market-Beating CEF #2: An Energy Fund Dropping A 9.5% Payout The 31.9% annualized return we’ve seen from the Adams Natural Resources Fund (PEO)
column43: which yields 9.5% today
column44: is astounding on its surface. But if you think for a second
column45: it makes sense: Oil was crashing five years ago and actually hit negative prices a couple weeks after the pandemic began. So crude had nowhere to go but up! And the large cap energy stocks this fund holds—PEO currently has ExxonMobil (XOM)
column46: Chevron (CVX) and EOG Resources (EOG)—naturally benefited. Plus
column47: this fund’s massive 11.7% discount to NAV is a strong value for that huge income stream
column48: which essentially turns gains from energy stocks into income without you having to buy and sell these stocks yourself. No question about it: Brave contrarians who chose this well-run energy fund five years ago have enjoyed strong gains and healthy income. The fact that we can still get in at a discount means PEO still has appeal
column49: despite that strong run. Market-Beating CEF #3: Massive Returns At An Unusual Discount This last fund is our top performer of the three
column50: and what a performance it’s been. If you’re unfamiliar with PIMCO
column51: it’s a specialist investment firm that operates in the bond market and has a lot of funds that outperform their indices; in the world of credit
column52: it’s considered one of the best
column53: if not the best
column54: there is. So the outperformance of the PIMCO Dynamic Income Strategy Fund (PDX) isn’t too surprising
column55: but the size of that outperformance certainly is. An unbelievable 47.3% annualized return over the last five years
column56: as of this writing
column57: makes PDX an unquestionably powerful wealth builder. But five years ago
column58: you had to be very brave to buy it. Consider that PDX invests in junk bonds
column59: and buying at the start of a global pandemic
column60: during which bankruptcies were expected to be the norm
column61: took an iron-willed contrarian indeed. As I write this
column62: PDX yields 6%. And it’s worth noting that the fund’s payouts have been volatile since its inception in 2019. However
column63: it currently trades at a 6.8% discount
column64: which is unusual for a PIMCO fund (most trade at a premium)
column65: so we’ve got an extra margin of safety and an opportunity for discount-driven upside
column66: too
column67: even after this fund’s incredible five-year run. Michael Foster is the Lead Research Analyst for Contrarian Outlook. For more great income ideas
column68: click here for our latest report “Indestructible Income: 5 Bargain Funds with Steady 8.6% Dividends.” Disclosure: none Editorial StandardsForbes Accolades"

That creates a situation where the Fed is torn between curtailing price gains and supporting growth.Advertisement“Today’s report highlights the difficult predicament the Fed is now confronting
column19: ” Citigroup (C-5.18%) economists wrote. “Ultimately
column20: we expect Fed officials to dovishly lean toward their full-employment mandate
column21: but that would depend on upcoming data and in particular on ... March spending and inflation.”AdvertisementTrump’s trade war is also weighing on investors. The 25% tariffs on all car
column22: truck
column23: and auto part imports that the president announced Wednesday evening continued to depress automakers’ stocks Friday
column24: with Stellantis (STLA-11.91%) dropping 4.1%
column25: Ford (F-4.53%) down 2%
column26: and General Motors (GM-5.14%) off 1.1%. The ADRs of Toyota (TM-4.10%)
column27: Volkswagen (VWAGY-1.91%) and Honda (HMC-3.58%) also declined.Separately
column28: Lululemon’s (LULU-6.41%) stock plunged 14% after the athleisure wear maker’s sales and profit projections missed analyst expectations. The company has scrambled to update its product line to compete with trendier brands
column29: Reuters (TRI-1.54%) reported.AdvertisementChris Grisanti
column30: chief market strategist at MAI Capital Management
column31: said he was surprised by the relatively benign market reaction to the auto tariffs
column32: which were more hawkish than he’d anticipated. He now expects new duties on April 2 to also be hawkish
column33: possibly followed by another muted reaction from investors.Chairman Jerome Powell and his fellow policymakers will probably wait longer to see the impact of Trump’s tariffs
column34: especially on inflation
column35: before making any decision on cutting rates
column36: Grisanti told Quartz.Advertisement“The only way I see Trump getting the Fed on his side is if he tanks the economy
column37: ” Grisanti said. “We can slice and dice these economic numbers as much as we want
column38: but the Fed is on hold until we get some tariff clarity.”

column1: 2025-03-29T15:59:00Z;These 100-Year-Old Funds Are Kicking Out Near-10% Dividends;Different yield and maturities for bonds and interest on stock exchange screen.getty Over the last couple of years
column2: we’ve seen a quiet trend in investing—and today we’re going to tap into it with two funds with near 10% dividends.  That’s right: enough to pay you back just shy of 10% of your initial buy a year in dividends alone.   What’s more
column3: these two income plays—closed-end funds
column4: to be precise—have been around for nearly a century
column5: with one dating from 1927 and the other having launched in 1929. That last date
column6: of course
column7: is notorious
column8: as it heralded the start of the worst market crash in history.  I bring these two CEFs up now because their long institutional memory gives them a level of reliability that few other funds can match. And there’s something else that favors both of them now
column9: too—that quiet shift I mentioned earlier. I’m talking about the move from growth stocks to value stocks that’s started to pick up momentum in recent months.   We can catch a hint of that when we look at the performance of the large caps in the Dow Jones Industrial Average compared to small caps
column10: as shown below by their benchmark index funds: the SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF Trust (DIA)
column11: in orange below
column12: and the small-cap-focused iShares Russell 2000 ETF (IWM)
column13: in purple:Large Caps OutperformYcharts MORE FOR YOUGoogle’s Android Update—Bad News For Samsung And Pixel Users‘NYT Mini’ Clues And Answers For Thursday
column14: April 10Microsoft’s Free Upgrade Offer For 500 Million Windows Users  That nicely sets the table for our two centenarian funds. ‘Centenarian’ CEF Pick No. 1: General American Investors Company (GAM) The General American Investors Company is the oldest of our two CEFs
column15: but not by much. It’s been around since 1927 and holds reliable cash cows like Republic Services (RSG)
column16: Apple (AAPL)
column17: Alphabet (GOOGL)
column18: Microsoft (MSFT) and Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A).  The fund has delivered an annualized return of 8.9% over the past decade
column19: as of this writing. It’s caught our attention now because
column20: at my CEF Insider service
column21: one of the things we look for is a fund with what I like to call “discount momentum.”   That’s where a CEF’s discount to net asset value (NAV
column22: or the value of the fund’s underlying portfolio) is still wide but is slowly moving toward par. And that’s the setup we have with GAM now. Take a look.GAM Discount to NAVYcharts Currently
column23: GAM trades at a massive 13.3% discount
column24: as you can see above
column25: and that discount has been shrinking over the last year as market volatility prompts more investors to favor value over growth. In the past year
column26: GAM has also paid out a 9.3% dividend
column27: which is a massive amount of income for one fund. Now it is true
column28: that most of the fund’s income is paid out in one big yearly special dividend
column29: so you’ll have to hold on to the fund for a full year to be guaranteed the full payout. But that’s a good thing: At CEF Insider
column30: we see funds as something to be held for the long term. ‘Centenarian’ CEF Pick No. 2: Adams Diversified Equity Fund (ADX) Our second fund
column31: the Adams Diversified Equity Fund (ADX) was launched just a couple years after GAM
column32: in 1929. That
column33: of course
column34: sent it headlong into the biggest market crash of them all
column35: and the Great Depression. But that experience was the start of the fund’s build-up of the institutional memory that still helps guide its decisions today. That’s a big part of the reason why we bought ADX in one of our first issues of CEF Insider
column36: back in July 2017. Since then
column37: it has delivered a 193% total return for us
column38: as of this writing
column39: showing its long-term mettle. ADX and GAM take similar approaches
column40: with Microsoft
column41: Alphabet and Apple being common top positions
column42: but ADX also has a large holding of NVIDIA (NVDA)
column43: which is part of the reason why the fund has posted a bigger “NAV return” (or the performance of its underlying portfolio
column44: including dividends collected) over the last decade. (ADX’s total NAV return is in orange below.)ADX Outperforms GAMYcharts ADX’s strategy isn’t too risky
column45: though
column46: as it emphasizes investing in high-quality
column47: large-cap companies
column48: ensuring both growth potential and dividend reliability. Plus
column49: its total dividend yield of 10.9% for 2024
column50: combined with a relatively low management fee (for a CEF) of only 0.61%
column51: makes ADX one of the cheaper CEFs on the fee front. On average
column52: these funds have fees around 2% on average. What’s unusual about ADX is that it has outperformed the market over the last decade and
column53: over the last couple of years
column54: the gap between its profits and those of the S&P 500—shown by the performance of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY)
column55: in orange below
column56: has grown wider:ADX Outperforms SPYYcharts ADX should trade at a premium for delivering these gains
column57: yet it sports at an 11.4% discount as I write this. That means there’s upside as this “secret” income monster becomes more widely known. The move from growth to value
column58: which we discussed with GAM above
column59: should also help ADX move on to more people’s radar. A Strategy For Using ADX Or GAM To Build Long-Term Wealth At this point
column60: you might be wondering which fund is ideal: the cheaper GAM or the higher-performing ADX? Ultimately
column61: what matters with CEFs is that we combine the best funds in different asset classes—and funds with different investment strategies—while maintaining a high level of quality among our picks. That way
column62: when one falters due to a selloff
column63: you can rebalance toward that dip-buying opportunity as another CEF outperforms. CEFs are particularly useful for this kind of rebalancing due to their high dividends (yields average around 8% as I write this). You’ll not only compound your returns by following this approach—you’ll build up a healthy income stream over time
column64: too. Michael Foster is the Lead Research Analyst for Contrarian Outlook. For more great income ideas

column62: Bloomberg Dealing With Uncertainty If you own your stocks as an investment — just like you’d own an apartment
column63: house
column64: or a farm — look at them as a business. – Warren Buffett Warren Buffett’s mentor
column65: Benjamin Graham
column66: taught him much about investing. Graham’s most essential lessons were to analyze stocks as a business and not react to short-term fluctuations in the quoted price of a stock. Buffett has said that chapters eight and twenty of Benjamin Graham’s “The Intelligent Investor” book are the bedrock of his investment process. Graham thought investors should look at stock holdings as owning a part of various businesses
column67: like being a “silent partner” in a private company. Hence
column68: stocks should be valued as a portion of the company’s intrinsic value
column69: not as something constantly changing in price on the stock market. An investor should take advantage of the stock market’s fickle view of a company or concerns about macroeconomic factors rather than allowing it to dictate what one should do. Valuing stocks as a business and purchasing stock with a “margin of safety” enable investors to ignore the market’s emotional ups and downs. For Graham
column70: the “margin of safety” meant buying at a price below the “indicated or appraised value
column71: ” which should allow an investment to provide a reasonable return even if there are errors in the analysis. The recent market turmoil makes it an optimal time to revisit investment first principles. Given the growing downside risk to the economy and the current inflationary environment
column72: investors should find comfort in owning quality companies with pricing power when searching for opportunities during any selloff. Quality is defined as high returns on capital
column73: consistent earnings
column74: and low debt levels
column75: which should help the company survive a possible economic slowdown or tariff-related challenges. For example
column76: consider Constellation Brands (STZ)
column77: which is best known for owning the rights to Corona and Modelo beers in the U.S. It also owns some wine and spirits brands
column78: but beer accounts for about 80% of its sales. Potential tariffs on Mexico could negatively impact its beer earnings since almost all its beer is produced in Mexico. It seems unlikely that a tariff headwind will erode the long-term value of its beer brands
column79: even if profitability could be dented in the short term. Corona and Modelo have two of the best growth profiles among beer brands
column80: and alcohol consumption tends to remain relatively unscathed by economic downturns. Notably
column81: there are fears that the GLP-1 diet drugs and a growing preference for cannabis could weigh on long-term alcohol consumption which could be a structural headwind. On the other hand
column82: the stock is now selling for a multi-year low in valuation across several metrics. Constellation boasts a solid balance sheet and free cash flow generation to sustain it through a possible recession or tariff-related disruption. Conclusion Just as the zenith of economic and earnings optimism in early 2025 gave way to creeping concerns about the durability of growth under pressure from possible tariff increases
column83: maximum pessimism will eventually give way to a better reality. History tells us that better stock returns follow maximum policy uncertainty. Whether next week’s tariff announcement provides that bottom is unclear
column84: but markets have shifted from pricing in a benign environment to a more difficult path. Current data points to an economic slowdown rather than a recession
column85: which bodes well for reasonable returns from the correction bottom. Macroeconomic forecasting is fraught
column86: so one should still admit that the odds of a recession have risen
column87: and no one truly knows the eventual outcome. Though most are rightly concerned about the downside risk from tariffs
column88: there is an upside if this pressure results in better trade terms for U.S. companies
column89: and the tariffs can be reduced in the short term. In addition
column90: the focus could shift to more market-friendly topics of tax cuts and deregulation. In any case
column91: investors must always deal with uncertainty and unpredictable market volatility. Warren Buffett and Benjamin Graham have provided a better blueprint for dealing with this by focusing on the health and valuation of the underlying businesses rather than the macroeconomic environment or the movement of stock prices. This focus doesn’t avoid the volatility but allows one to use it to their advantage if executed correctly. Just as Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/A
column92: BRK/B) keeps more than enough cash to pay insurance claims without touching any stock investments
column93: investors should have enough cash and bonds to cover short-term expenses to ignore any depressive states of the stock market and perhaps benefit from taking advantage when they invariably occur.
